151448477.review:
I wish there was a "meh" option for recommending a game.
I wouldn't say it's bad or good, it really depends on what you want from it.

If you like exploration and being a loot goblin this game is really fun. One of the best parts about it is that nearly everything that can be picked up is useful, from being valuable enough to justify carrying it for sale later to the fact nearly everything can be broken down into base components that can be used to upgrade weapons/armor.

If, however, you want a good story driven game with deep dialogue and a plot where your actions have consequences then this game is an abysmal failure. Nothing you do matters and for the most part you don't really have a choice in anything, at most you get a few options but all of those option will lead to the same consequences so they're pointless anyways. 
It's a near identical theme to bioshock infinite where it turns out all of your choices are irrelevant but instead of the game telling you that the entire time then driving the point home at the end Fallout 4 tells you that you have choices but instead rips the rug out from under you at the end when you realize no matter who you choose to stand with at the end the world you helped create in the final act is identical to the one you started with. 

Buy it if it's on sale for $5 and not a penny more, it's not worth full price.

151276441.review:
Fallout 4 es un mundo vivo como Fallout 3, bien pensado y diseñado, pero el desarrollo de la experiencia de juego se ve empañada por un crafting que para mi es abusivo con un modo de construcción que tienes que "moddear" o "glitchear" para hacer las cosas medio bien, el desarrollo de juego no es para nada tan fluido como el del Fallout 3, juego que para mí es mucho mejor que este Fallout 4, por mucho que digan y quien diga lo contrario es porque no tuvo el placer de jugar al Fallout 3 en su momento, además la gestión y los ataques constantes a tus asentamientos, te cortan el rollo, cuando estas en medio de una misión principal,  te sientes obligado a hacer un "Fast Travel" a tu asentamiento para defenderlo dejando la misión a medias, cortándote el rollo y casi hasta perdiéndo la noción de lo que estabas haciendo o ibas a hacer, cosa que me da muchísima rabia en los juegos con historias intensas como éste.

En definitiva el juego es muy bueno, mucho mejor gestionado y diseñado que el actual Starfield, con muchos menos bugs e infinitamente mejor caracterizado y aunque mi review viene con 8 años de retraso desde que salio el juego, le doy mi pulgar hacia arriba, juegos así aunque no sean perfectos hay que defenderlos como el que defiende sus juegos favoritos porque le gustan o como el que defiende su casa en una guerra, más vale tarde que nunca como dicen en mi pueblo, Fallout 4 es un mundo abierto disfrutable, entretenido, apasionante, con un punto negro que son los asentamientos que te obligan a estar constantemente encima de ellos cortándote constantemente el rollo como he dicho, pero con una optimización soberbia desde el principio a final del juego, técnicamente atrasado pero buenísimo en todos los aspectos. Tengo que decir que aunque no esta al nivel del Fallout 3 y anda varios pasos por detrás de éste recomiendo encarecidamente Fallout 4.

Me gustaria destacar las labores de programación que, aunque a día de hoy, 8 años después y aunque el juego ya esté algo pasadito, aún conserva algunos bugs, y reafirma la teoría de que Bethesda nunca termina de pulir sus juegos en este aspecto. Y me gustaria reiterar que la herramienta de construcción que te brinda el juego, como he dicho, es una pifia por lo que a mi respecta es muy mejorable, adaptada a las omnipresentes consolas que me tienen cansadísimo, además de que como he dicho arriba, en ocasiones, tienes que "glitchearla" para poder construir bien tus asentamientos y hacer coincidir las piezas, labor la cual te lleva demasiado tiempo y se hace muy tediosa y pesada, a veces te hace pensar que estas en un "city builder" antes que en una aventura de acción-rol, pero que por "h" o por "z" no llega a exprimir al máximo ninguno de los dos géneros por culpa de una microgestión excesiva de asentamientos que en un juego como este debería haber sido más liviana, pasas más tiempo construyendo que siguiendo las tramas del juego, al final te  rompe el rollo y obstruye constantemente la experiencia de juego, dicho sea de paso es mi opinión y como cada cual tiene la suya, que cada uno opine lo que quiera, buenos días.

151179320.review:
Fallout 4 es la última entrega de la aclamada saga post-apocalíptica de Bethesda. El juego nos transporta a un Boston devastado en el año 2287, donde tendremos que sobrevivir en un mundo plagado de peligros mutantes y radiación luego de una guerra nuclear.

Gráficamente, Fallout 4 es impresionante. Bethesda ha creado un mundo abierto increíblemente detallado y lleno de coloridas locaciones por explorar. Desde las ruinas de la ciudad hasta los bosques y pantanos, cada región tiene una identidad única. El nuevo motor gráfico permite tenercombates épicos con decenas de enemigos sin perder fluidez.

En cuanto a jugabilidad, es el Fallout más pulido hasta la fecha. Disponemos de cientos de objetos para recoger y construir cientos de estructuras en nuestros asentamientos. El renovado sistema de progresión y perks da una gran libertad para desarrollar nuestro personaje. Los tiroteos también se sienten mejor gracias al uso de miras en primera persona.

La historia nos engancha rápidamente al tener que buscar a nuestro hijo desaparecido en este peligroso mundo distópico. En nuestro viaje conoceremos fascinantes personajes con notables actuaciones de voz y tendremos que tomar decisiones difíciles. Las misiones son entretenidas y repletas de giros inesperados.

En definitiva, Fallout 4 es un juegazo imprescindible para los amantes de los RPGs de mundo abierto. Su enorme mundo está lleno de retos, historias y secretos por descubrir que nos tendrán explorando durante decenas de horas. Sin duda, Bethesda ha creado la mejor entrega de la saga hasta la fecha.

150967655.review:
Fallout 4 is a controversial entry in a beloved series. Especially after the masterpiece that is New Vegas, people found it hard to accept the voiced protagonist, more restricted quest choices, and the sudden introduction of crafting/settlement management mechanics. I often see people say that it's "a good game, but not a good Fallout game", and I am inclined to agree with this. 

Despite its flaws, I find it to be a really enjoyable shooter with a nice overall aesthetic and good soundtrack. The shooting mechanics themselves are far and away better than previous entries in the series, and there is an absolute ton of quest content to get through. The companions are likeable, and as always, it is a very moddable game. It also made the brave choice of including a DLC where 90% of the content is only playable if you become a raider. 

If you want a vanilla-like experience with enhancements akin to FNV's Viva New Vegas, I would recommend The Midnight Ride (https://themidnightride.moddinglinked.com/), and you can add Sim Settlements 2 to this if you're interested in that part of the game too.

It's an older game so the graphics and animation aren't up to standard for modern AAA games, but it's to be expected. I have to say, the story is great; for me it was emotionally evoking, as [SPOILER!] it tells a story of a man, husband, soldier on a dedicated journey to find his way back to his son. Who was so viciously taken by cruel mercenaries, the very ones who cruelly murdered his wife in front of him, ripping the child away from the lifeless body. It was a very sad, yet motivating start; I mean, the fact that a video game made in 2015 can make a guy be emotionally involved, that's impressive. I could just be sensitive, or lack the understanding of a "good" game story, whatever that means. 

But in my opinion ... I really believed this was a great story. If you're into fallout esk' games and enjoy a good story. Then I'd definitely say this is a good game to grab, but if your on a budget, it goes for a great price when on sale.

It's the game I was worried Fallout 3 would be. 

The soul of the series is gone, the whole thing is a bit too far on the taking itself serious side of things now. RPG heart has been ripped out, it's a pure ARPG/looter shooter now. 

Wasteland is absurdly crowded now. In FO3 and Vegas it felt like you could walk a few minutes in a direction before finding a landmark. Here there is some.sort of landmark every 100 ft. 

That said, it's still a fun, good game. I really enjoy the settlement mechanic, and the gunplay is closer to what could actually be called a shooter. The companions are definitely some of the better showings in Bethsoft's catalogue. 

I'm only 20 hours in and level 20 at the time of this review, but I'm having a good time so far. Just wish this wasn't necessarily a mainline FO game, would have worked better as FO:Settlers or something.

150613737.review:
Fallout 4 is an action-adventure FPS game with some RPG elements sprinkled on top of it.

Unlike previous Bethesda RPGs, the playable character in Fallout 4 is voiced. The Sole Survivor also has an established background (married with a son, worked as a soldier or lawyer). With these two factors combined, Fallout 4 gives an impression that the players are always role-playing as a carefully curated character crafted by Bethesda (i.e. not a blank canvas).

Fallout 4's role-playing may be different and the writing may be questionable at times, but the open-world is still beautifully crafted and the exploration is still classically Bethesda.

I love this game, even if I am not a fan of horror/scary/postapocalyptic worlds, this one feels somehow cozy. I love coming back to this game. It is so massive with all the dlcs that me playing it for the first time in 2023 still did not reach the middle of the story after 100 hours. I love repairing and building back sanctuary hills, especially after I realized how to set up electricity in the houses. I wish that objects interaction would be less clunky in building mode, but otherwise it feels relaxing to come back to the game and spend a couple of hours in this weird world, listening to old music and finding new fun stories to discover. 
I really love the mini-stories in the side-quests. Even reading stories in terminals feel interesting, even though I usually skip reading things in games. But somehow those stories unwrap from the end to the beginning, end figuring out what happen in this office or in an old vault leads to interesting conclusions and feels rewarding. 
I also love the moments, when you don't expect game to react to some minor decisions, and suddenly finding consequecnes of your decision. For example many citizens of Diamond city joked about "lemonade wall" when I provided yellow paint instead of traditional green to the painter in one of the side quests, which was fun and unexpected to hear. 

For me this game has a special place and I love its glummy and charming world.

150456240.review:
A good old game.

First, let me introduce this game to players who have never played it. This is an open world RPG game. We will control the character to freely explore the wasteland, shoot enemies and monsters, and search for supplies and weapons and equipment.

To me, the gameplay of this game is relatively interesting. Our operating characters have complete, multi-path upgrades. We can choose the direction of evolution that suits us. In addition, the collection of weapons, equipment and garbage in the wasteland world is also what attracts me, because I can't help but want to find the materials in those cabinets and safes, even if they are garbage. Running a community in the wasteland is also a highlight of this game. We can build various facilities in the communities we control to develop local residents.

Speaking of shortcomings, the relatively rough graphics and UI must be mentioned. After all, this is a seven-year-old game. If you are a player who cares about picture quality, then this game may disappoint you. Also, many of the side tasks in the game are not designed with much care and are boring to complete. But the main tasks are still available.

I think it's a decent looter shooter, though without mod the games was tedious to play. I'm no lore guy, but the way the difficulty work is just: The higher the difficulty, enemy do more damage and becomes tankier. So what happens in high difficulty is that it's just resource dump, not the good kind because the shooting feels a bit off (better than fallout 3 and NV though).

So to alleviate this, I kinda cheated by installing a mod that enables the random critical hit back from the old game. So I got the new critical hit system from fallout 4 which was a guaranteed hit after a few hits in VATS and the random critical hit. This makes the game better, but for a multi million game designer to not realize this sounds like incompetency. That and also the AI and the way combat can be trivialized by huffing on stimpaks. Fallout 3 and NV is like this but not to a worse amount, especially now that enemy scales with level, the enemies are going to get tankier.

Content wise I think the game is just too big with no so memorable stuff. I remember the fallout NV plant vault to this very day and how dangerous it was to venture there. I remember the fallout 3 combat system and how busted Luck was. Here, I just remember Cait, which was a companion on the game that I kinda like because how sarcastic she was. The main story just felt off by the end and I think the final nail in the coffin that made me give a negative review is that the ending was bugged.

Yes, a multi million dollar company couldn't figure out that a main quest for their game had a consistent bug preventing you from progressing. So what happen is that you need to open a console and type in a code. If that isn't immersion breaking, I don't know what is.

Also fuck encumbrance mechanic.

150428585.review:
Fallout 4 presents a captivating evolution of the Fallout series, offering a compelling dive into a post-nuclear wasteland. With over 500 hours of gameplay on console, it proved to be a highly memorable experience. Set in the meticulously crafted ruins of Boston, the open-world environment immerses players in a dark and desperate atmosphere, turning exploration into a journey filled with discovery.

The transition to a first-person shooter system adds a refreshing dynamic, skillfully balancing RPG elements with engaging shooting mechanics. Extensive character customization influences the narrative and interactions with factions, enhancing the overall depth of the experience. The "shooter-looter" aspect excels, featuring a diverse array of weapons and armor, coupled with strategic elements like resource management and colony construction.

While Fallout 4 is not without criticisms, such as graphical standards and occasional AI unpredictability, its strengths far outweigh its shortcomings. In conclusion, Fallout 4 stands as a successful evolution of the franchise, providing a captivating and immersive journey through the post-nuclear wasteland. Whether a series veteran or newcomer, the game offers depth, customization, and thrilling moments, earning its place among the genre's standout titles.

150408308.review:
Let’s go back to 2007. Fallout 3 would come out the next year, sure, but the world was blessed with that year’s entry in the famed Tony Hawk series: Tony Hawk’s Proving Ground… and the vastly, vastly superior Skate from Electronic Arts. It’s hard to state what it was like, after playing nearly [i]every[/i] Tony Hawk game, how EA’s skate felt, especially since Tony Hawk was seemingly in the trough of its relevancy (and little did we know how much further it could fall.) Some of those later Hawk games are classics (Underground 1) or, at least, pretty good (UG2, maybe American Wasteland?) but it was clear the idea well was nearly empty, with you spending what felt like more and more mission time [i]not[/i] skateboarding. And, yet, I still played Proving Ground for dozens of hours. Why? Because it was still Tony Hawk. No matter how much nonsense they tried to bolt on the mechanics, they still worked. It wasn’t until the entire engine went through the woodchipper after Neversoft was relieved of command did I sign off entirely.

So let’s now turn to Fallout. This was another game series I played extensively. When Fallout 4 was released, I was not very happy and passed it by. I wasn’t interested in the setting of Massachusetts. I wasn’t interested in exploring the Institute. I almost always skip The Replicated Man quest in Fallout 3. I just didn't care.

So I decided to finally pull the trigger and purchase 4. Oh boy. The opening salvo was nearly a quitting moment in itself. Old world! Nuclear war! Go to the vault! Shady Vault-Tec experiment! Plot starts!! Radroaches! Funny robot! Bloatflies! The dog! Molerats! Raiders! Good guys! Power armor! DEATHCLAW!

This is a  theme park ride of the Fallout Experience, not an action RPG with a 40+ hour main campaign. It signaled to me that something was amiss. In a bubble, there’s plenty of things going okay here. The plot has urgency and momentum, even if the direness of 4 is more amplified than, say, finding your perfectly capable adult father in DC (I was waiting for that achievement you get in The Forest – “Shouldn’t you be finding your son?”.) The combat is very good. The landscape is pleasantly despairing, full of abject failure and misery and contrast between how different groups of humans adapt to awful circumstances. Almost every location is a story within itself and exploring with no expectation of a reward, outside of just attempting to figure out what on Earth happened, is a joy. Companions are, by and large, fun and compelling and complex. And the overall political landscape – three good guy factions with their own impulses (civilian resistance, military strength, subversion) aimed against a larger bad guy faction – is simple and done fairly well. The radio is absolutely incredible and might be the best part of the game: the songs they picked out or are original recordings are dissonant in the best way, underscoring that you are a lost weirdo without a home in a land that is actively hostile to you. 

Outside of the bubble, I can’t help but feel disappointed. The approach to combat, to me, favors run-and-gun way heavier, deemphasizing VATS and thus one of the last mechanical ties to the original Fallout games. Enemies get spongy damn near immediately, evoking to me the worst part of having Broken Steel installed for 3. Structurally, the Commonwealth is more than a little bit like the Capital Wasteland – the open hills as your “starter area” with realms of difficulty demarcated by a urban environment. Like Fallout 3, you’re often in the ghoul/raider/Super Mutant/mercenary combat matrix with such alarming frequency you wonder how anyone managed to settle here at all. You’ll often find yourself besieged and assaulted vertically. There’s so, so many fire escapes and roofs and it is logical but it doesn’t make it any less annoying. There are way, way, way too many mini-nukes and Fat Man’s lying around to make sense at all. You’ll probably encounter a raider with a Fat Man 30 minutes into your playthrough, in one of the most logical thoroughfares for what to do after the introduction, and it will [i]piss you off [/i]. The dungeon-like nature of notable locations reveal themselves almost immediately, having you ask why so many raiders are just holed up somewhere in outer Boston. Vault-Tec apparently abandoned all pretense of being inscrutable-but-unscrupulous and is now just plain evil. A warhead created what feels like miles of irradiated wasteland here, despite the White House being *directely hit* by a nuke in Fallout 3 and DC is still, like, there.

But that’s the old stuff. What about the new stuff? The settlement system is an interesting thought but demands mods to be passably engaging. Without, it feels like Fallout’s worst tendencies regarding its world repackaged as gameplay feature. You don't encounter communities that that have been affected by a setback but could otherwise grow and thrive (or at least leave), but groups of pathetic, dirty, sick wastrels that are waiting around to be killed horribly without your help. It’s also great to know that nobody in the 250-something years of the Fallout timeline ever learned basic carpentry and that you are no exception. Gun and armor improvements are similarly fascinating, but the negative of them comes from removing the lion’s share of unique, named weapons and armor from the game world in place of “legendaries” with random effects. And while you can kind of make your own Terrible Shotgun, it’s not as fun, to me, as finding it in the landscape. In the hands of a slaver merchant. Who you will kill, of course.

The story is… whatever. I wonder if they simply were thinking “let’s approach the father/son dynamic of Fallout 3 from the inverse angle?”. It does what it should most of the time, but Fallout has always been mostly black-and-white. The most thought-out bad guy faction was the Legion, in terms of policies that people that aren’t stupid and/or sociopaths would actually believe, but even going for them was radically dumb in terms of what it does to step-by-step gameplay. The second twist in Fallout 4 may give you that momentary pause that other “evil offers”, like President Eden’s wish for you to poison the entire coast’s water supply, do not, but the Institute is still hilariously backwards and bumbling outside of making fake people. So, it’s kind of funny. It’s like if you found James in DC and he’s trying to domesticate Yao Guais.

You’ll probably invest in the Game of the Year edition. And you’ll be hit with a bunch of questions in the gamut of DLC about the expanded Fallout universe that might be fascinating for a minute or for a mod. Hey, buster! Did you ever want to build your own Vault? (No, not really.) Don’t you want to build some of those RobCo robots? (I guess, maybe..) Don’t you want to face off again with the Mechanist?! (Huh??) Do you want to create a bunch of Minecraft-esque contraptions that still pull from the same extremely limited resource pool, requiring multiple travels to merchants to buy shipments of materials? (No.) Do you want to lead a raider gang in what feels like the first draft of the Pitt DLC? (Absolutely not.) Don’t you want to explore a gorgeous landscape, a great story, whole new enemies, and one of those fantastic integrations of mechanics and setting like the best ideas from Point Lookout and Dead Money? (Why wasn’t this just the game??)


Ultimately, describing my experience with Fallout 4 would be like describing a visit to Disney World. The experiences are diverse and entralling. But, in the moment-to-moment? Well, when in Disney, you probably spend, like, 80% of your time bored, frustrated, or waiting in line. But, overall, did you have fun? Probably. That's why I have as many hours as I do in Fallout 4. Like how Tony Hawk's Proving Ground was still Tony Hawk, it's still Fallout. So, yeah, I recommend it. But I'm not happy about it.

150239513.review:
Not-terribly-realistic post-apocalyptic Skyrim.  But with GUNS! (and no spiders!)

Seriously, everything that made Skyrim great is pretty much there in Fallout 4 (except, sadly, melee weapons aren't that good in Fallout 4) - open world with a good-sized map, long main story/quest that is ignorable, grand opening that wears on your nerves by the 3rd or 4th viewing, creepily identical children, hundreds of places to explore, instant healing potions as well as food items that do the same (check out YouTube's Fallout Vs Skyrim https://www.youtube.com/watch?=XBlhXKjSy6M ), and literally (and I mean LITERALLY literally, not "hipster ironic emphasis that isn't literal") tens of thousands of mods on Nexus and other websites to rework the game in whatever direction(s) you'd like.  Yes, even those directions (and no, don't tell me about it).

It's also got settlement building, which I find extremely fun and nearly impossible to do in Skyrim.

There are arguments that Fallout 4 is more a First-Person Shooter (FPS) with Role-Playing Game (RPG) elements; and there's plenty of criticism for Bethesda's story-writing and plotting - and it's Bethesda, which means bugs-a-plenty - but I found it engaging for hundreds of hours.  

If you can get the GOTY version on sale, do so.  If you liked Skyrim and would like to play something a little different - or if you're a little sick of modding Skyrim, or your modded Skyrim caught fire and died - even full price would be a bargain.

I'm playing on an AMD 4core 4GHz, 24Gb RAM, and a 4Gb NVidia GTX760 - all of which is kind of puny by modern gaming standards - and it runs well (but maybe I have low expectations) with about 900 mods twisting the game into closer alignment with what I want.

150214846.review:
In terms of overall gameplay, it's my favorite Bethesda 
[strike]RPG[/strike] shooter (I haven't played Starfield yet, so I have no idea if it's better or worse). There's plenty of cool locations and characters to find, and I actually had a lot of fun with the settlement building aspect. Combat-wise, the gun play feels good, and there's plenty of variety in the weaponry, and weapon modification is always nice. 

Now for the elephant in the room, the actual role playing... The whole dialogue system boils down to "Yes", "Yes, with a joke", "More information?", and "Not right now". It's a pretty railroaded (pun intended) experience, which would've been fine if the player character was an interesting-developed character. The Witcher 3 does a similar thing, but Geralt is a fleshed out character with his own morals. And even that game has more dialogue options, or role-playing choices for that matter. 

Overall, it's not the best written Fallout game, but it's still great fun.

149891290.review:
I want to hate this game. 

Story

In Fallout New Vegas you had the option of helping the first town of civilians defend themselves or join the bad guys. Fallout 4? No! You can't kill Preston. 
In this game every character assumes you are a good person. Even when you join the institute. The faction that everyone is scared sh*tless of. I realized this when I read the paper piper types up about you at the end of the game. 

"But perhaps the most compelling reason not to give up hope just yet is the fact that, if my sources are correct - and I know they are - the Institute is now under direct influence of someone many of us have already met - the Vault Dweller. That lonely figure who came into our settlement searching for a missing child, and clearly found something else entirely. And maybe, just maybe, the Institute is all the better for it." - Piper

Another issue I have with the story is the fact that In Fallout 3 you could find your father WITHOUT anyones help. In fallout 4 you cannot find Kellog or your baby until you find Nick the detective. Nick and Piper are way more forced onto you in the game and deserves some of the hate that Preston gets. At least you can do a complete playthrough without interacting with him. 

Gameplay

-Best in the 3d series. Fallout3/NV had so much janky movement it always felt like your characters was sliding across the map.

149830670.review:
In short, it's a great game.

In full, Fallout 4 got a lot of hate for not living up to the expectations that the previous installments set but honestly, it's a pretty good game from a standalone perspective. Sure, the dialogue isn't as rich as New Vegas's dialogue and the choices you make in F4 seem to have less of an impact than they did in FNV but the aforementioned elements aren't "bad" so to speak, they're just not as good as New Vegas's. So, if you've never played New Vegas before playing F4, you won't really feel like the story's really weak or lacking, nor is the dialogue. The factions are good, they each have their own unique ideologies and selling points in order to draw you in and, in my opinion, they're similar to New Vegas's factions in their uniqueness.

As for the gunplay and mechanics, they're the best in the Fallout franchise, obviously since F4 was released in 2015. So you won't be needing any hitmarker mods or recoil mods, the guns are visually well designed and their feedback and impact are on par with any other FPS released in 2015.

And if you found Fallout 3's world to be too desolate or FNV's world too sparse (even though it's set in a desert), then you'll find Fallout 4's world and environment to be a quaint blend between feeling post-apocalyptic enough but not [i]too[/i] desolate and dead: you can always hear gunfights erupting in the distance, or a super mutant blowing himself up with a mini nuke at some Brotherhood of Steel squad with a supporting Vertibird hovering over the battlefield. Diamond City feels very comfy given how such a large number of people are making do in a baseball stadium, it's a nice concept. The world feels alive and you'll never know what you may run into after rounding a corner in the streets of downtown Boston.

Overall, it's a great game and I would suggest you give it a try.

149825739.review:
[h1] An immersive wasteland experience like no other! [/h1]
[h2] Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5) [/h2]



Fallout 4 on Steam has been one of the most immersive and captivating gaming experiences I've had in recent years. From the moment I stepped out into the wasteland, it was clear that Bethesda had put an incredible amount of detail and effort into crafting this post-apocalyptic world.

The graphics are stunning, showcasing beautiful landscapes and highly-detailed environments. Exploring the vast open-world of the Commonwealth was a joy, with each location feeling unique and full of secrets waiting to be discovered. The attention to detail in every nook and cranny really adds to the sense of immersion and makes every moment feel like an adventure.

The game's story is equally engaging, with a compelling main questline that kept me hooked for hours on end. The character development system is well-designed, allowing me to customize my character and playstyle to suit my own preferences. The choices I made throughout the game had real consequences, further enhancing the depth and replayability of the narrative.

Combat in Fallout 4 is incredibly satisfying. The gunplay feels tight and responsive, and the use of VATS (Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System) adds a strategic element to every encounter. The variety of weapons and modifications available allows for a diverse and personalized playstyle.

One of the standout features of Fallout 4 is the settlement-building system. Being able to construct and customize my own settlements, complete with farms, defenses, and even attracting new settlers, added a whole new layer of gameplay. It was incredibly satisfying to see my settlements thrive and evolve as I invested time and resources into developing them.

Overall, Fallout 4 is a must-play for any fan of open-world RPGs or the Fallout series. It offers a vast, immersive world, a gripping story, satisfying combat, and countless hours of gameplay. 



[b] -To the world that was. Mankind shall never see its like again. [/b]

Alright, screw you guys, I'm Cartman from South Park, and I'm gonna explain the plot of Fallout 4, but you better listen up 'cause this is super cereal!

So, Fallout 4 is like this crazy video game, m'kay? It's set in a post-apocalyptic wasteland after a nuclear war, and you play as this dude or dudette who wakes up from cryo-sleep in Vault 111. But, whoa, your kid gets kidnapped, and that's not cool, bro!

You gotta find your baby and make sense of this messed up world, and along the way, you run into some really weird people and creatures. There are super mutants, ghouls, and these nasty Raiders who just wanna kill you, which sucks big time.

But it's not all bad – you get this cool Pip-Boy thing on your wrist, which is like a fancy wrist computer, and it helps you keep track of stuff and manage your gear. Plus, you can make friends with some cool companions, like Dogmeat, the loyal pup, or Nick Valentine, a synth detective who's pretty awesome.

And the story, oh man, it's like a rollercoaster. You gotta choose sides and make some tough decisions, like, should you help the Brotherhood of Steel, or maybe side with the Railroad or the Institute? It's like being stuck between a Rockzilla and a hard place.

So, you fight, you explore, and you do a ton of stuff, all while trying to solve the mystery of where the heck your kid went. And trust me, it's a wild ride through the wasteland, full of danger, adventure, and plenty of Nuka-Cola. Just remember, you're the boss, and you can be the hero or the villain – it's your call, dude!

149723317.review:
I first played Fallout 4 in 2017 and was left rather disappointed. Having poured over 500 hours into Fallout: New Vegas beforehand, there were many infuriating regressions and dumbed-down RPG mechanics. The main story of the Sole Survivor attempting to find their son in the ruins of the Commonwealth is sub-par, very few of your choices actually matter and the main gameplay additions feel incredibly superficial, adding nothing to the role-playing elements. If you're a Fallout purist,, you'll turn your nose up at so many elements; the depth, lore and strong writing of the older entries have all been thoroughly neutered.

However, on a second run with mods installed and playing the game on its own terms, I found an addicting looter-shooter with plenty to like. If you don't rush through the main story and go through the regular cycle of exploring new areas, killing enemies and grabbing all the loot you can find, Fallout 4 does succeed. The gunplay has been tuned up considerably, the amount of customisation for your equipment (including the updated power armoured suits) is excellent and some companions do offer up a likeable personality (a rare thing for a Bethesda game). Despite the skills system being absorbed by the perk chart, there is still some room for differing play-styles as well; all of it takes place in a varied and interesting environment that ditches the flat terrain of the Capital Wasteland for more verticality.

In short, you shouldn't go into Fallout 4 demanding a serious RPG with tons of depth and complexity. Treat it like a toy sandbox you can play around in without worrying about consequences or deeper meaning and put it down when you're finished. The series may have gone downhill in recent years with 76 but this entry will still tide you over for a while. The GOTY edition is often on sale and the modding community is still very active; both receive a decent recommendation from me.

Even if you get 100% on the achievements in Fallout 4, It's very likely that there is still content in the game. The stuff after the "end of the game" is still fun but feels like a grind at times. Pardon me for typing this in but the game somewhat feels like "The Sims: Fallout edition" after getting most of the story done. Even though i don't actually play Sims games and the settlement building for me is a nice extra, like a game within a game.

I played this game when it came out and was very excited to play. I even changed the date and time or used Virtual Private Network on my computer, In order for me to play Fallout 4 as early as possible. 

My first play-through was siding with the Institute because of family matters obviously in terms of the main character. Teleportation was neat but it didn't really do much but provide a cool effect when fast-traveling (I didn't notice if game time passes the same rate or not with or without teleportation). 

I didn't actually play much after numerous DLCs came out for Fallout 4. I played for a little while with a fresh new game, sometimes with modifications or no mods. Sometimes I would notice the new content but i was often unable to distinguish the DLC with non-DLC content which is a good thing. 

This game sometimes makes you think of possible creative branches for your character's narrative or possible story outcomes for other characters. When it gets "quite" or there's a moment in your game-play where there's nothing much to do but to try and improve your gear, That's when (In my personal experience) it hits me or I think of 'Maybe if i did [x], then [y] would [z]. I would've had option [A] instead of [B]'.

Because of the paragraph above (Referring to the multiple possibilities and outcomes of player choices). Having multiple instances of play-through is definitely a must if you're into role-playing games. If you choose the alternative of which is playing for the story content , Then i suggest you save your game progress at moments where player choices are required.

Fortifying settlements is enjoyable, especially with DLC content. Each DLC is unique and each takes half or less time as the main story.

149673813.review:
[b]Backlog, my nemesis[/b]

I initially began playing [i]Fallout 4[/i] back in 2019 (4 years after its release) but it ended up on my backlog for an additional 4 years. Not sure what happened as I invested more than 20 hours into it and I loved every minute of it. In any case, I'm glad I finally managed to complete it this year with over 130 hours spent with the base game and its story-oriented DLC, Far Harbor.

[b]The story[/b]

The start of the game is just superb. This time we start in the "present" and witness the nuclear blast itself (from a safe distance, of course) then we end up in a vault which will be our safe haven for many years to come but not in a way you'd think as we are put into stasis. We witness not only the murder of our wife but the kidnapping of our son. The objective is clear as we set out into the Commonwealth after waking up: locating our only next of kin once and for all.

[b]The graphics[/b]

This is a sequel released many years after its predecessor so, as one could expect, the graphics look much better. But where [i]Fallout 4[/i] really shines is the colour palette itself. For me number 3 looked way too simplistic or dull (if I may). Number 4 finally shows us how an post-apocalyptic world can look like. 

[b]V.A.T.S. and weapon customisation[/b]

The targeting system was already great back then so this is something one can only enjoy here when it comes to combat. As for weapons: there are TONS of objects (materials) we can find that we can use for weapon customisation at benches. Some make the damage done greater but in certain cases we can change how the gun itself operates. Do you prefer a rapid-firing laser weapon instead of shooting one destructive beam? Off you go then! It's also fun modifying the many melee weapons available.

[b]Post-apocalyptic Sims[/b]

An interesting part of the game that was a bit of a hit-and-miss for me. Factions return and the first group you meet are the Minutemen. You also go back to the starting position (where you used to live pre-war) to build your own settlement. Most of the objects you find can be scrapped for materials and even unnecessary parts of buildings can be immediately scrapped on the spot. 

Then you start putting down structures (a radio beacon will be important to attract fellow survivors) and even pieces of furniture inside houses (or in the open). As the people arrive you can assign them to help defend your settlement or start working on the fields (yes, you can have your own crops). This is an exciting part of the game but it can quickly become tedious. I wish scrapped materials were universally available across the many benches but this is not the case. 

Preston (from Minutemen) will regularly tell you what new group of people require your assistance and by completing these quests we'll get access to new posts and, consequently, their benches. Then, from time to time, we have to defend these outposts (not that anything bad happens if we fail such a quest). These quests are mainly good for exploration purposes so I decided to focus on the story and move on instead.

[b]Factions and companions[/b]

Once again we have the opportunity to join various factions. This affects the ending and we have several we can get. I liked how the story wasn't black and white. While the Brotherhood of Steel wanted to look good there were many aspects of their approach I didn't like. The game gives you the option to meet the Minutemen first that represent the - sort of - neutral option. Here's an important piece of information as it is not obvious: you CAN join multiple factions later; quests for the others will still be available. If you have reached the point-of-no-return the game will notify you anyway. Don't be hesitant when the option to join is offered.

As for companions? We have many who comment on the actions we do or the decisions we make during a dialogue. This affinity meter can increase to a point where romance options open up and we can receive a special perk from our companion when maxed out. I can't really comment any further as I preferred Dogmeat from start to finish - your character is actually considered travelling alone this way so additional perks are available making you stronger. It's a wasteland and it's the end of the world already: I need no human beings, just a trustworthy pet as my only loyal friend (whose animations are superb).

[b]What else?[/b]

The game has tons of places to explore. You even find points of interest outside the boundaries of the map. Mutants, ghouls and deathclaws return and we now have a lot of androids (synths) as enemies. Animal parts can be cooked which is a must for additional effects and radiation elimination. There are many recipes not just for cooking but also for making our own chemicals.

I loved this game. After a while I felt weaker but with additional perks (around level 25-30) you can become pretty strong so much so that almost nothing will pose a challenge. It should also be noted that there isn't really a cap level so feel free to pick any perk you like. 

Fallout 4 is still a fresh experience for me. I loved the exploration part and I preferred ditching any companion for Dogmeat - it was just us out in the wasteland exploring long-hidden vaults and completing multiple missions for any allies we could get to know. I tried only a couple of radio stations to listen to and only for a short period of time - not even songs could save me from the preferred loneliness. Thus, I recommend you the same loneliness in the wasteland of Commonwealth.

149546749.review:
As per the hours played, I've completed the entire game. All missions, each faction, and all DLCs. It really is hard to express my thoughts without writing an endless think-piece, so I won't bore you with much.

Fallout 4 takes place in a post-apocalyptic setting, with a 50's futurism aesthetic. It does this style justice, and with creativity. Characters are diverse and charming. 

Dialogue options can be insanely hilarious (mostly coming from the Sarcastic option).

Skill progression is creative with the SPECIAL tree. Character creation / looks give many options for personalised looks.

Many people would like to compare this to Skyrim since this is also a game from Bethesda. And in many respects, the games are comparable. But their unique styles (fantasy vs futurism) and varied characters absolutely makes this a worthy experience.

I'm looking forward to reviewing Starfield

Mixed review.

While the launch of Fallout 4 was disastrous it was still crucial to the series regardless of the attempts going on. Though I have to admit the gameplay is still true to the original series just- I guess you could say underwhelming at best even with the newest engine used. You do have a vast world to explore on a certain degree but you know, your character level of course limits you but not that highly. There's old guns returning from Fallout 3 and New Vegas and some new. I mean it's Fallout, there's not much to say other than it being the same old fashioned example. However...

There's a lot to grasp where there's bugs and side hiccups on the table: the main course here is voice acting along with lots of selections. But be advised the choices in this game are way more narrowed and linear. It almost makes you dislike it with shame cause really they're not bad and not great either. You'd wish they sounded a bit more like pretty much any older entries of the games. Because A. choices sound too lifeless and make less impact how you progress and no matter how you act it's gonna sound same and B. with voice acting combined it sounds too robotic and soulless. Yes, I know there's lots of dialogue and recordings went into making these but my god does it hurt to know that some of it does no impact what-so-ever. And don't get me started on the biggest highlight of this game, the construction and sandbox mode.
You're very limited at start but once specific perks are obtained it's so plain easy to build whatever you want. It's basically your own Sim City example but feels way too boring and overused. Why overused, you may ask?
It's used in main story and DLC stories. It's enforced in which is the most disliked example to put it. I don't hate it but it's just so unnecessary thing to put into the game. It DOES give your settlers inside your area for interactions and all but I swear I get no satisfaction value from it. It's very optional for a gimmick both for free sandbox use and well annoying standards to force it in to the main story. Oh and highest difficulty is a bigger bullet sponge experience than in older games. Don't get me wrong, plot and story has its own uniqueness and I appreciate it. But it's way toned down and tries to copy out Fallout: New Vegas with the choice of 4 endings and siding with four factions. It's not bad for replayability value but like I said it feels undertone at best. Feels less rewarding for getting any ending than in older series.

Oh and DLCs, they're good. They have exotic looks, story, newer enemies and some guns to display. Although it's same deal to what I said above. At least some characters return from older games so that's a plus.

In all honesty Fallout 4 is not a bad bad entry for the series. It just could've become more if Todd Howard wasn't self obsessed with rushing things and lying but we all know how it goes. But really, take this game for a ride when it's on sale. If it suits you, it suits you if not then don't bother. Cause in reality it's same deal how Fallout 76 just more "expanded" and "co-op" friendly.

La salsa bechamel, o salsa blanca, es una receta básica de la cocina que se convertitá en tu aliado a la hora de cocinar pastas, gratinados, y mucho más.
Ingredientes:

4 cucharadas de mantequilla
4 cucharadas de harina
2 tazas (500 ml) de leche entera
Una pizca de nuez moscada molida
Sal y pimienta a gusto

Derretir la mantequilla en una olla ancha. Cuando esté burbujeando, agregar la harina. 
Mezclar la mantequilla y la harina con una cuchara de palo hasta formar una pasta espesa. Cocinar revolviendo por un un minuto, a fuego bajo, con cuidado de no dejar que se dore.
Añadir ⅓ de taza de leche y revolver vigorosamente con un batidor de mano hasta que la leche se haya absorbido por completo por la pasta de harina y mantequilla. 
Continuar agregando la leche en tandas de ⅓ de taza, batiendo vigorosamente hasta que se incorpore por completo a la salsa sin formar grumos. 
Cocinar la salsa por 2-5 minutos a fuego mínimo, hasta obtener la consistencia deseada.Tomar en cuenta que la salsa continuará espesando conforme se enfríe. 
Sacar la olla del fuego y sazonar con sal, pimienta y nuez moscada. Usar de inmediato.

149419988.review:
Brief overview of opinions on the Bethesda Era of Fallout games before and including Fallout 4:
Fallout 3, shallow but was overall an alright transition to a new way for the Fallout Franchise and I would consider a great starting point for people interested in Fallout. The Dlcs where a very mixed bag of ‘Alright’ to ‘Why you do this?’
Fallout New Vegas, not flawless but pretty damn good and kept more towards the originals than 3 did with a more complex story and better built area. Dlcs were also pretty good.
Fallout 4 has some good points but overall is just an entry better off skipped with a brief summary than actually played vanilla. 
While it’s been a while since I’ve played the story and haven’t touched most of the dlcs yet there are reasons for it. Short handed reasons: They ruined the designs of guns by making them left-handed and having a modification mechanic that shouldn’t exist as it is, would’ve taken different types of each ammo instead of needing to put a stock on a rifle. The plot was way too shallow and uninteresting with its factions and characters, also suffered from the “Overpowered MC issue” that wasn’t handled well. Building mechanic, the way it was added just played into the “Overpowered MC issue” and helped ruin the game. And overall, the experience was far more draining than previous and future entries. (Yes, fallout 76 was more bearable to play since there were friends to play with; doesn’t mean 76 was or is good, it very much isn’t, but that should give a pretty good idea of what it was like playing this game.)
Will mention that I don’t believe that the ability to mod a game makes it suddenly a good game, I believe games should be played vanilla for their first playthrough and judged on that. Mods can make any game good, but it cant fix the foundation of a game being bad, thus the bad review. 
Will I be going back to the game to finish the dlcs? Probably, just to get them done. Going back to replay the story? It took me numerous days, 6+ hours alone as of the day I’m writing this to boot the game back up to see if my save file was still there… so very unlikely.

Ways they could’ve fixed the issues in my opinion:
Story: While it’s just the reverse plot of Fallout 3 taking place in that one area mentioned from that one side quest in Rivet City. It could’ve been much better if they had made it more mysterious, hinting at the existence of the ‘main bad guy’ instead of bluntly throwing them at the player. Also, could’ve made the reason behind what they were doing more morally complex (been a while so don’t fully remember but it was just meh from what my memory tells me). Example of how the devs could’ve hinted at their existence: have people in the player’s settlement slowly be replaced over the course of the beginning search and have the player’s settlers mention how some people seem different so it forces the player to keep an eye on them, leading to ways to further the overall plot. Plenty of other plot points that would need fixing and plenty of characters that could’ve been way more interesting. (Quick rant about characters, why they gotta treat Arthur Maxson like a personal OC that’s way too overpowered for his own good)
Power Armor: Fallout 3 don’t get training till the end of the game or by doing a dlc. Fallout NV, work for power armor either through the BoS or the Enclave with interesting side quest that aren’t required for the main story (Kinda on the BoS one). Fallout 4 took the idea of powerful military grade armor and defenestrated it and just gave it to the player in the opening act and made it a constant for the entire game… Personally, just wish they didn’t touch power armor and had it as a reward for a hidden/difficult side quest like breaking into a military base, but cant use it until trained by someone you have to find. Or could’ve just have it so the player character was a mechanic for Power Armor suits but wasn’t trained to use one, so they find them throughout the waste and collect parts to build their own and hunt down an old army buddy to learn how to use it, maybe one of the factions would have a dude to train them.
Weapons: modification mechanic sacrificed weapon design and “realistic” functionality for something that didn’t need to be complex at all. A lot of the weapon designs are disappointing (Looking at you Assault rifle, tube having waste of space), and for some reason all of them are meant for left-handed shooters. They really could’ve just kept the ammo complexity from Fallout NV and added some modifications like silencers, different mag types, etc. without making all the weapons look beyond stupid by taking off components.  (Fun fact rant about 76 that I believe is also in 4, the Light machine gun requires both a stock and a certain part around the front of the barrel to function… and they decided to make that locked behind modifications; so basically, they made the gun completely useless in its default form.)
Settlements: As it was implemented, just ruined fallout 4 for me. It plays into the “Overpowered MC issue” by making them a master builder while also being a master in just about everything else. It would’ve been so much better leaving that mechanic to a settler, let the player create a blueprint somewhere and provide materials to said NPC settler and have them build it over the course of in game days (More NPCs the faster it goes). The settlers feel completely useless and such a system would’ve fixed it, giving them different jobs to manage and build the settlements would make the “restoration of the wasteland” feel more whole, instead of one person doing all the work for the Commonwealth.

149407484.review:
With the 76 being predatory and Starfield being Mediocre, I reinstalled Fallout 4 as it looks to be the last classic game from the Old Guard at Bethesda.

Pros: 
• Environmental Storytelling.
• Well written companions.
• Well designed landscape.
• Hours of replay-ability.
• One of the best modding communities in gaming.
• Tries to promote fun with the apocalypse, instead of painful accuracy like STALKER.
• A dedication to patch the game when it released in rough shape.
• Fun gameplay mechanics and a sense of actually rebuilding the world, thanks to settlements.

Cons
• Very diluted storytelling compared to previous Fallout or TES games.
• DLC's *feel* like DLC's. Each feels separate from the gameplay and Far Harbor is often skipped because of that.
• Creation Club never released as a Season or Collected Bundle. Several Creations need patching to work correctly together.
• Engine bugs left for the community to fix.
• Not given proper send-off like Skyrim's Anniversary Edition. PR was rude or silent on Socials when questioned about it.

TLDR: It's still a fun game in 2023 and unlike 76, it still feels like Fallout.

149396740.review: So far this game has been quite entertaining to play, though that doesn't mean that I don't have any criticisms to make. Gameplay itself is quite fun and I am one of the few people apparently who likes the whole settlement building part (what's not to love about being a benevolent dictator?), however it can get even better through the usage of mods. Now this game has a very large mod compatibility as thousands of them can be found with over 43,000 alone being on Nexus with over 1.3 billion downloads worldwide. Of course me personally the several mods that I have are for the most part lore friendly since I obviously want to still be playing a Fallout game but with various features to enhance certain things where I find lackluster vanilla wise or perhaps as an extra fun addition, though there are tons of non lore friendly mods out there if that is more or less your thing. Overall the gameplay is great, the story is mediocre, and mod compatibility is definite.

149258309.review: This game's a mess and in terms of Bethesda's legacy is all over the place. The voiced protagonist basically takes away the general role playing feeling Bethesda was known for. You're playing the character with a missing kid and dead spouse and because of the set up, you never really feel like you're playing your own character. The companions are finally compelling, but they're also tied so hard into the story line that you can't really do anything meaningful with them that strays too far outside of the story path. The world is better, but they do such weird things with the sense of scale that it's never convincing in the way it could or should be. The story is yet another in a long line of poorly written stories that sadly Bethesda has become known for. The BOS ending basically is just a rip off and remix of Fallout 3, the Railroad are comically bad and never really give much of a reason for their pro-synth stance other than it just being there, the Minutemen don't even really have much of their own story beyond having to rebuild because they were such failures the first time, and the Institute is so poorly written that nothing they do makes any sense compared to what they say, or their stated "goals" which also contradict their actions. I have a character that runs the Institute and I still really have no clue what they're trying to do or why they go about what they say they want to do the way that they do it. So what's good about this game? The settlement system is a great concept, but poorly executed, and the combat isn't bad anymore. It's not good, but it isn't as awful as it was in Fallout 3. Overall, a poor experience with obvious cut content around every corner, a nonsensical story, graphics that always put Bethesda games in a AA category despite them making AAA money, and a main character that's about as interesting as a glass of ice water. Not worth it for more than a few dollars. Fortunately at it's age, you can usually get it for little more than a few dollars.

149241840.review:
Fallout 4 is a game that divides opinion, and it's not hard to see why. Yet, one can't help but be drawn into its post-apocalyptic world, where choices are rarely clear-cut, and humour often shines through the gloom.

The game's RPG elements may not be as deep as some franchise fans hoped, and the decent story doesn't match up to the quality seen in earlier Fallout titles. But for all its flaws, Fallout 4 has one undeniable virtue—fun. The shooter mechanics are solid, the open world is expansive, and the atmosphere is quintessentially Fallout. Even without VATS, the game manages to deliver satisfying gunplay and exploration.

It's also a game where you can't escape the lure of modding. With a vibrant modding community constantly churning out new content, Fallout 4 can be transformed into a more rewarding experience, rectifying many of its issues and opening up endless possibilities.

The graphics may need to be top-tier by today's standards, and the occasional bug is par for the course with a Bethesda title. But these minor inconveniences fade when you immerse yourself in a vast wasteland with countless stories to discover.

The verdict? Fallout 4 is a game that isn't without its flaws, but it's a game that, much like the post-apocalyptic survivors it portrays, keeps on going. The colourful world, diverse companions, and the lure of mods make it a game worth revisiting, especially if you're a fan of the Fallout universe.

149194889.review:
The Negatives (I like to end on a high note):
-Limited deviation from the role of "concerned parent" for storytelling, when compared to older titles
-On that note, the main story isn't particularly engaging. It's not horrible, but when you can't really build your own story around it, that's going to be more apparent.
-New SPECIAL system replacing skills with Perk levels removes another layer of character stat customization
-DON'T GIVE US A FULL SUIT OF POWER ARMOR THAT EARLY INTO THE GAME, BETHESDA
-It can be hard to find a good difficulty level: Lower difficulties can result in you chewing thru enemies, higher levels can turn them into sponges, and Survival places extra limitations that some players won't enjoy

The Posititives:
-Sarcastic Dialogue options are Spider-Man worthy banter
-Weapon and Armor modifications give you a lot of freedom.
-Genuinely funny sidequests all throughout the Commonwealth
-Settlement Building can be genuinely fun
-Gunplay, while still not realistic, feels quite good overall, and is generally a major upgrade from 3 and New Vegas
-Dogmeat is the goodest of boys. The other companions are fun, too, I guess, but Dogmeat tho
-Survival Difficulty, while brutal, does a good job of making the Commonwealth feel like a genuinely dangerous place
-You now have a reason to hoard all of that junk you find



Overall, if you're looking for a WRPG like the older Fallouts, you won't find as much of that here, but you will STILL find a fun game. Play it as more of an action-adventure game with RPG and crafting elements blended in.

Note: If you intend to use Mods on this game, make sure to follow a guide like "The Midnight Ride" so you don't create glitchy results. My personal no 1 recommendation would be a mod to make DogMeat not count to the companion limit, which was the original plan during development

[h1] The Good [/h1]
• [u]Expansive Open World[/u]: Fallout 4 presents a vast and immersive open world, teeming with intricate details, dynamic weather, and a sense of post-apocalyptic beauty.

• [u]Robust Crafting System[/u]: The game introduces a comprehensive crafting system, allowing players to modify weapons, armor, and even build and customize their settlements.

• [u]Compelling Story and Characters[/u]: The narrative is enriched by a compelling main story and memorable characters, each with their own background stories and quests.

• [u]Dynamic Dialogue System[/u]: The inclusion of a dynamic dialogue system adds depth to player interactions, providing a sense of agency in shaping the protagonist's personality.

• [u]Exploration and Discoveries[/u]: Fallout 4 rewards exploration with hidden stories, loot, and unique encounters, encouraging players to venture off the beaten path.

• [u]Variety of Factions and Choices[/u]: The game offers diverse factions and branching story paths, allowing players to align with different groups and make impactful decisions.

[hr][/hr]
[h1] The Bad [/h1]
• [u]Voice Protagonist Limitations[/u]: The voiced protagonist, while a new addition, may limit the range of role-playing options for players seeking a more personalized experience.

• [u]Repetitive Settlement Tasks[/u]: The management of settlements involves repetitive tasks that can become monotonous, potentially detracting from the overall enjoyment.

[hr][/hr]
[h1] The Ugly [/h1]
• [u]Limited Role-Playing Impact[/u]: Despite the array of choices, certain decisions may not have the profound impact on the game world or story that players anticipate.

• [u]Occasional Bugs and Glitches[/u]: Fallout 4, like many open-world games, is not without its share of bugs and glitches, with some issues impacting the overall stability of the experience.


[hr][/hr]
[h1]Overall Score: [/h1]
[h3] 9/10 [/h3]

Firstly, the game's rich and immersive open-world environment allowed you to delve into a post-apocalyptic wasteland, replete with intricate details and a sense of desolation, which could have captivated your interest. Additionally, the freedom to make choices and decisions throughout the game, often with significant consequences, may have contributed to your enjoyment by providing a sense of agency and personal investment in the game's outcome.

The game's narrative, which revolves around the search for your character's son and the various factions vying for control in the wasteland, could have engaged your interest with its intricacies and moral dilemmas. The opportunity to customize your character's appearance and abilities through the game's robust character creation and leveling system could have appealed to your desire for personalization and progression.

Furthermore, the dynamic combat system, featuring a wide variety of weapons and a versatile power armor system, may have provided you with satisfying gameplay experiences. The diverse cast of non-player characters, each with their own stories and quests, could have enriched the game's world and offered numerous opportunities for interaction and exploration.

The game's modding community, which created a wealth of user-generated content and enhancements, might have extended your enjoyment by offering additional features and gameplay experiences. Overall, your enjoyment of Fallout 4 could have been derived from the combination of these elements, creating a holistic and engaging gaming experience in the post-apocalyptic wasteland.

149026060.review:
Fallout... Fallout never changes.

In the year 2008, my eldest peers, playing these games, wondered when they'd get to play the new Fallout games, and the DLC they'd never seen. They got their wish, when Bethesda Softworks acquired Fallout, from Interplay, for $.5.75 million. The fans awaited ruin, instead... something miraculous happened... they began to use the games, not as a monetary sink... but as a nearly limitless source of entertainment. People began to enjoy gameplay once thought the realm of future. Amazing DLC, ingenius mods, lore expansion... But then... in the 21st century, people awoke from the Bethesda Magic, years of betrayal led to shortages of community faith... The entire industry unravelled... Entertainment became a distant memory... It is now the year 2023, we stand on the brink of total ruin... And I am afraid. For myself... For Fallout... For the community... Because if my time playing these games has taught me one thing... It's that Fallout... Fallout never changes.

Try this game out, buy it on a sale, get all of the DLC, have fun for hours and hours, it's worth experiencing.

148945210.review:
About time i did a review i guess...
Its not the worst Bethesda title, well certainly not now... *cough*

Short version, No, Not unless you intend on modding away all the jank, inconsistencies and general design laziness. Vanilla Fallout 4 is average at best, well then you get to nuka world... oh my... Bad, so bad.

I love the fallout IP, the setting, visual theme, vault boy/imagery.  So yeah i dig the 1960s atomic age punk whatever. The map itself has some great little spots, It still captured some of that Bethesda magic in simple wandering/exploration/Discovery. The world building was pretty good, some assets were pretty good, almost nice and it was an OK shooter looter.... but thats about it.. 

The story ahhh... well lets just say unless your heavily invested in the backstory/narrative slapping you in the face you end up playing as the worlds worst husband/father. The writing/voice acting was quite bad in almost all instances, those companions oof...

The game is a technical shit show, visually and with its mechanics, consistency in its systems is almost non existent, like nobody knows what resolute means... Example of lazy/unfinished design, the armor layering. There are countless outfits in the game and a small hand full has the ability to have armor layed over top. You can wear that dirty as long-johns under your armor but not that spiffy suit, are you mad sir? Its not the bulk of said outfit or anything logical for the most part, they just stopped adding attach points (Bone Data) to clothing at an arbitrary point.

I literally used the XEdit tool (Mad Props to the xedit team) to copy Bone Data from other similar outfits onto the ones missing it, and its perfectly functional, imagine having access to there tools in development and just not bothering. This type of thing persists through every facet of this game and every other, like boy they really struggle with how much things weigh.... basic stuff, baby town frollicks.

There is no apparent focus, or i can only imagine they must split up individually, all work on a different segment of a system and or mechanic in complete isolation from one another, then probably at the half way point they just take what they each have and kinda cobble it together...

The technology *cough*, Inner workings, game systems and mechanics ARE NOT!! always just inherently enjoyable by themselves...or half done, smashed together...yesh. They are generally there to support, like ya know, important stuff... things like World building, Story/Narrative, Meaning and connection, Interaction, Emotion, Purpose...  Its like they are Poppy from Mythic Quest (minus her genius and charm)  in the scene where she realises she "doesn't see it" "Im a glorified mechanic" she says. She doesn't even see fun like a normal person, she builds systems but has no insight on how to pull them together in coherently enjoyable ways - Someone at the top has some bad un-diagnosed ADHD, no like seriously, in a not funny, its destructive and disruptive to my life kind of way.

So why the insane hours you say? Its obvious, Mods. The sheer talent in the modding community boggles my mind, they take something so half baked and janky and just pull it together. It great once you can get things  to work, consistently and fix glaring oversights and visual laziness.  So thank you Beth for the "framework" and some decent assets, but please kindly fuck off and get on you knees and thank the modding community for allowing you to exist this long. Oh and MS should give the IP back to Obsidian.

With this, then Fallout 76 and now Starfield/Starfail/Nahfield you pick, I think its honestly time for the modders to move on, stop dragging this ragged sad company any further. They dont deserve your talent or your time. Connect with each other, pool your resources and talent and just make your own games, let Bethesda die in all there pants crapping glory because Bethesda....... Bethesda never changes.

148861269.review:
Ah, Fallout 4, the game that turns the post-apocalyptic wasteland into your personal playground. It's like a mix of Mad Max and The Sims, with a dash of radiation poisoning to keep things interesting.

Now, the story kicks off with the typical "Hey, I'm just an ordinary suburbanite" scenario, but within minutes, you find yourself frozen in cryostasis, your spouse murdered, and your baby kidnapped. And just when you think life couldn't get any worse, the world ends in nuclear fire. It's the kind of day that makes Monday mornings feel like a spa day.

But then, you wake up in the ruins of Boston, and it's your job to make the Commonwealth great again, one mutated creature and rusty tin can at a time. And what's the best way to do that? Well, by hoarding every piece of junk you find, of course!

Fallout 4's crafting system is like a post-apocalyptic Pinterest board. You'll collect everything from coffee cups to toy cars, break them down into raw materials, and use them to build settlements that look like they were designed by a deranged interior decorator. If you're not sure what I mean, try building a house with an exploding car chandelier and a toilet that's mysteriously placed on the ceiling. It's a work of art, really.

But it's not all about home improvement. You've got a whole wasteland to explore, filled with ghouls, super mutants, and an endless supply of raiders who clearly didn't pay attention in shooting school. Oh, and don't forget the Deathclaws – they're like T-Rexes on steroids, and running into one is basically a game of "Can I outrun this before I become lunch?"

Then there's the iconic Power Armor, which is like having your very own mini-mech suit. You'll feel like Iron Man, but with a bit more rust and a lot less charm. And nothing says "I'm here to kick butt and scavenge junk" like stomping around in one of these bad boys.

Of course, let's not forget the companions – each with their own quirks and baggage. They're like a post-apocalyptic therapy group that follows you around. Piper, the sassy reporter, loves to uncover the truth, while Nick Valentine, the synth detective, has a heart of gold (or at least circuits of gold). And then there's Dogmeat, your loyal canine companion who can carry an entire arsenal in his invisible backpack. Who's a good boy? Dogmeat, that's who!

In a nutshell, Fallout 4 is the kind of game that makes you feel like a true survivor, a junk-collecting, mutant-fighting, settlement-building legend. It's a world where you'll encounter bizarre characters, make morally ambiguous choices, and laugh in the face of radioactive danger. So, grab your Pip-Boy, load up your Laser Musket, and get ready for a post-apocalyptic adventure that's as entertaining as it is irradiated. Welcome to the Commonwealth, Vault Dweller. Enjoy your stay!

Old review below:

Pretty standard Bethesda jank so far, I can tell I'm probably going to play it a lot, and probably mod the bejeezus out of it, but the game's just not good.
Sure, it's got neat stuff mixed in, like a pretty good weapon modding system, but the game itself is pretty bad for the price point they still try to sell it at.
Too many glitches, too many weird Bethesda issues, paid modding (go to Nexusmods instead, pls), an awful dialogue system limited because of your character being voiced, the total removal of the skill system (now it's JUST the perks), a pretty thrown-together "town" building system meant to pad playtime, a pretty weak plot, the total removal of YOU being "you" by forcing you into a relationship and marriage with someone you personally have no attachment to (also, why should *I* care about the baby? I just met him and the whole intro segment was slow and tedious,) all characters can use all weapons and armor, VATS is still OP unless your agility is really low, and power armor getting handed to you for free at the beginning just feels like Bethesda wanted a "WOW" factor and couldn't think of anything better.

I mean, Bethesda and other mod-heavy games get a big free pass for being moddable, which really isn't something that a dev should get away with. Review the game as-is, then go to the mod websites, thumbs-up the modders, and maybe donate some money to them, don't give garbage devs like Bethesda a free pass for making subpar games.

148769189.review:
I vividly remember the moment when I gave up on Fallout 3: I was the ruins of some city, with a grey sky looming over the shredded grey concrete shells of buildings, and vast chunks of broken grey highway was wrapped up against, around, over and under huge chunks of grey concrete. My companion had gotten stuck somewhere in the grey sea of rubble for the umpteenth time, and it just suddenly struck me: This game isn't fun. It's just depressing.

A few years later, I recalled this experience to a friend of mine, and he assured me: "Fallout 4 isn't grey. It's got colors. And it's good." Having banked 1410 hours in game, I would have to say he was right.

Is Fallout 4 good RPG? Nope. The story is rubbish, the characters extremely shallow, and the skill tree is very meh. If you hate VATS, like I do, the skill tree is complete rubbish. Is it good because it is bug free and has good DLC's? Nope. Is it good because it's the best shooter ever? Nope. Fallout 4 is good game because it's fun, and it's fun because it's a decent shooter, with an OK open world, good atmosphere and a sense a humor. Slap some of the 1000's of existing mods on that, and there's a decent chance that the next time you emerge from the elevator of Vault 111, switching to the catchy tunes of Diamond City Radio as you ready your gun and take in the not-grey landscape, you'll be smiling, just like I do.

148702265.review:
This game is not a great full-on RPG, due to the dialogue system and NPC interactions, but it is a great RPG-lite / adventure game. 

Pros
- Gunplay feels really good compared to the Bethesda Fallout entries that came before it
- Characters are memorable and the companions are varied
- There is a use for pretty much every item in the game thanks to the settlements and crafting
- Decent progression. You do get power armor early on, but you have to have the materials to power and repair it which evens things out a bit.
- Interesting locations

Cons
- Dialogue system won't show you full options (fixable with mods). The tone that the lines are delivered in and the reaction from NPCs can go against player intentions (e.g. You are playing an evil character and pick an option for "I guess I'll have to kill you then", but the line is delivered as a joke and the NPC interprets it as such)
- Not a lot of reactivity other than around direct plot points. Typical Bethesda issue where I can be the head of the Institute, but there is no mention of it from key NPCs that should be aware of that.
- Not a lot of companion options for an evil play through

148675669.review:
Other than Fallout 4, I have also played Fallout 3 and New Vegas, with NV being my introduction into the Fallout universe. It was a ton of fun to play, and I was so excited when I was finally able to get a hold of FO4 (Now with voice acting!). So yeah, I had semi high hopes that I would enjoy this just like the others...except I didn't. 

Don't get me wrong, it had some amazing moments! I loved the level design especially. I'm not sure of the proper word, but the vertical level design (how enemies could shoot at you from on top of buildings, bridges, etc.) was really cool and made things feel more action packed. I was loved the graphics. Although the game is almost 10 years old, it still looks amazing. I really like how much variety there is in character creation, since you can add burns, scars, freckles, wrinkles, anything. I changed my hair/scars throughout the story to reflect how the commonwealth is effecting my character. The companions are great as well, with most being romancable. 

The part that really made this otherwise great game bland was the lack of RPG elements. Sometimes what you say doesn't matter. The best example of this was when I told someone that I did not want to do their quest, yet it was added to my quest log anyway. What I love about RPGs is that I feel like I have an impact on the world around me and with FO4 I just didn't. Some of the quests were interesting (my fave involved a ship, a mother deathclaw, and a comic book character) but a ton can be summarized with go to this area, clear out the mirelurks/ghouls/supermutants/raiders,etc. than come back. Which is fine but it would have been nice if they spiced it up a little more. 

But worse of all, was the ending. It seems no matter what you do, you get a generic slideshow about how the commonwealth has changed you. I have over 300 hours in this game (including DLCs) so I didn't expect for them to mention everything I did but at least say something. All those settlements I helped, the companions, the people, none of them get mentioned at all so its almost like it didn't even matter. 

The best way to describe FO4 is vast but shallow like a pond. Like plenty of other comments said, if you're looking for a action game with light RPG elements, maybe you'll enjoy this one. Make sure to get it on sale though! But if you're looking for a RPG heavy game, look towards the older Fallout titles, because you're going to be disappointed with this one.
