I like older Bethesda games for their mindless exploration, looting, and very simple and hyper shallow RPG mechanics. It's like enjoying a McDonalds burger, you know its poor quality, poorly made, you know its not actually a great burger (or a great RPG in this case), its a cheap facsimile of what a burger is, designed for mass appeal and to generate money, yet my brain still likes one from time to time anyway.  I enjoyed my first playthrough of this game (heavily modded) in 2015-2016 too.

Now trying to replay Fallout 4 for the first time in about 6 years, the game is just a buggy PoS. The game's performance on a 3080 TI, Ryzen 7, 32gb ram is sub-40 fps at only 1440p. God rays settings in the launcher don't save, so I have to open 2 ini files to just make those options work, because this is too complex a concept for Bethesda Game Studios and their over 2 decades of PC port experience. (I hear god rays crash RTX users, so I have to brute force them off that way. They also used to tank the framerate when they actually functioned before by like 20 to 40 fps). 

Introducing just 6 or so mods just makes the game crash for no reason even though they all worked before for a several minutes, then after reseting the game and altering nothing, the game crashes once the game world is loaded and is unplayble. (after my 17 years of modding TES4&5, and Fallout 3&NV and not struggling with those at all.) The StartingConsoleCommand's break once you use F4SE, the feature just stops working and you need F4SE for mods. The anti-aliasing looks like vasiline is smeared on the monitor, real humans from BGS added it in and thought it looked just great.

Fallout: New Vegas makes this game look like a 6 year old's first grade art project. Play FO:NV instead, BGS cannot write good lore, make satisfying RPG mechanics like unique skill checks, or write good dialogue or characters. Seriously gotta stop supporting BGS, they're shockingly incompetent at PC ports, as well as core RPG game design too. They make shallow and technically broken garbage, just aiming for mass appeal and mass profits, while not knowing anything about how to make a good RPG. I will continue not buying Starfield for the rest of my life as that game looks like a Fallout 4 total conversion mod with literally zero innovation. Really FO4 in 2015 had zero innovation too.

I like this game but there's so many bugs that have never (and never will be) fixed. Bethesda is a terrible, greedy company. The game also has minimal replayability since you're forced to be this mother (or father) looking for their kidnapped son. There's minimal roleplaying options because the game forces you to be this character. In Skyrim, you were the dragonborn, but you could have been a thief, a wizard, or anything else you can imagine. In Fallout NV, you were the courier, but you could have chosen to be good or bad, or ignore your quest completely. In this game, you have no choice but to roleplay as a parent, and half of the dialogue options force you into being a "good" person. The dialogue system itself is terrible, since you have only four options to choose from and you need to guess what your character will actually say, since the dialogue prompt is incredibly short and sometimes the options are as simple as "yes", "no", "more information", and "sarcastic". Without mods, this game is fun maybe one time. If it weren't for the modding community I would have never touched it again. Years ago Bethesda tried to profit off of mods by creating the "creation club" thing for people to buy mods from, allowing modders to lock mods behind a paywall and take a chunk of the profit for the company. 

tl;dr shit game 1/10 fuck corporate greed

148550625.review:
[h1]PERSONAL RATING - 5/10[/h1]

The story is slow and only gets interesting towards the end, tons of side-quests that are buggy & repetitive, the atmosphere is great, okay gunplay & solid modding community. DLCs are mediocre apart from Far Harbor.

Recommend buying during a sale & if there is nothing better to play.

[h1]FULL REVIEW[/h1]
A quick note about me and this review - I enjoy fully completing games and all of its achievements. After experiencing everything the developers have released for the consumer, I only then write my opinion about the game.

[h1]STORY:[/h1]
The start of the game creates the right atmosphere through the events that happen, and after an hour or so, the story becomes quite shallow. Only at the end does it pick up and depending on your choices, ends abruptly.

In most dialogue encounters, you, the player, have four dialogue options to choose from that create the illusion that you're in control of the final outcome, while in reality, although it does have an effect, the final destination is linear. I understand this saves a lot of development time, but I do wish you were punished more for making wrong, different, or stupid decisions. 

There are a lot of side quests in this game that have their own little stories that are completely detached from the main story and some that are connected in non-influential ways.

During my playtime, I ran into a good few quests, including main story ones, that I couldn't progress without using console commands to fix them.

[h1]GAMEPLAY:[/h1]
A lot of content that also feels... useless.

Combat is a double-edged sword - there is a lot to it, but it is also simply there to waste your time. Enemies are bullet sponges depending on your difficulty, tons of different guns & attachments that are not really worth picking up, and legendaries are bonkers OP, making other equipment worthless.

V.A.T.S. seemed like an unnecessary addition to the game, but this might just be me, and a good half of the unlockable perks were either very weak or straight-up useless.

The world is vast and full of loot, so exploration can be fun for the first ten or twenty hours, afterward becoming quite dull. In some cases, loot distribution made no sense (i.e. caps can be found in locations that haven't been accessed post-war).

Quests are repetitive fetch quests for the most part, and with the core game being quite big, they are everywhere. Even those that are different in idea still share the similar process of going somewhere, killing enemies, scouting, and locating objective tasks.

Mods (like with any Bethesda game) fix many issues and create a better overall experience, so here's a short list of mods I wouldn't even bother playing the game without:

[url=https://www.nexusmods.com/fallout4/mods/9424]Place Everywhere[/url] 
Allows you to build settlements without ridiculous restrictions, turning this aspect of the game from being frustrating and uninteresting to one of the better parts of the game.

[url=https://www.nexusmods.com/fallout4/mods/44798]High FPS Physics Fix[/url]
Does a lot of things, but primarily removes the FPS cap of 60, making the game run at an enjoyable framerate.

[url=https://www.nexusmods.com/fallout4/mods/12465]Achievements[/url]
Re-enables Steam achievements if you decide to use any mods.

[h1]ADDITIONAL CONTENT:[/h1]
Most of the DLCs added additional stuff to build, craft, or play with, but in terms of the interesting storytelling, quests, and atmosphere, Far Harbor was the only DLC worth playing.

Nuka World was the least enjoyable one for me, as it felt to me like the most developer-to-player detached content. Forced to play evil path if you want to see the quests and other content, while also creating achievements that make me believe the developers don't play their own game and just put random requirement numbers in.

[h1]ACHIEVEMENTS:[/h1]
Quite a big portion of the achievements will be unlocked by simply playing through the game and completing quests. There are, however, a few that will require you to either start a new playthrough or load a quite early save. 

Like many other games, there are some achievements that are very specific in requirements but are not difficult to achieve.

148536384.review:
Oh, Fallout 4! Where do I even begin? It's like a post-apocalyptic wonderland that's as charming as a two-headed radstag. The vanilla game itself is a masterpiece, a veritable buffet of irradiated delights. You've got everything from super mutants to deathclaws, and let's not forget the ever-lovable Preston Garvey with his endless supply of settlements that need your help. 

The main storyline? Oh, it's a rollercoaster of emotions. One minute you're a happy suburban parent, the next you're frozen in time, only to wake up in a world that's been nuked back to the Stone Age. And let's not forget about the Institute. Ah, the Institute, my home sweet home. Some people might call them the bad guys, but hey, who wouldn't want to live in a clean, high-tech utopia away from all the dirt and radiation?

But where Fallout 4 really shines is its modding community. These folks are like the magical elves of the gaming world. They take an already amazing game and turn it into something extraordinary. Want to turn your power armor into Iron Man's suit? There's a mod for that. Want to replace all deathclaws with Thomas the Tank Engine? There's a mod for that too. The possibilities are endless!

And let me tell you, choosing the Institute was the best decision I ever made. Sure, they might be a little morally ambiguous, but who cares when you've got teleportation and synths? Plus, their cafeteria has the best Blamco Mac & Cheese in the Commonwealth.

In conclusion, Fallout 4 is like a radroach-infested diamond in the rough. It's beautiful, it's terrifying, and it's utterly addictive. And if you'll excuse me, I need to go now. My ever-growing R&D department needs funding and apparently saving the Commonwealth doesn't pay well. Who knew?

P.S.: If this review sounds like it was written by someone from a psych ward... well, let's just say that playing Fallout 4 for 37 hours straight will do things to your brain.

148506634.review:
The first Fallout game is one of my top ten favorite CRPGs.  I was skeptical of Fallout 3, but it turned out to be pretty fun.  I was perhaps even more skeptical of Fallout 4.  A relative gifted it to me when they found out that I hadn't played it yet.  It's been almost a decade since then, and I've dropped a lot of playtime in it.

Given the number of hours I've put into Fallout 4, I'd probably have to put it somewhere in my top 10.  It's odd, though, because Fallout 4 comes up short in a lot of places.  The role-playing is not very deep, too many of the quests are a bit simplistic and have only one solution, and the dialogue trees have been simplified to the point where you're mostly just saying "yes" or "no".  The world can be surprisingly responsive to your choices, but, especially in the main quest, you're railroaded through a quest without many options.  Despite these problems, it's is just so much fun to play that I often don't care.

Part of it is the open world exploration.  No matter how much they might stumble in other areas, Bethesda is quite good at this.  Part of it is the combat.  Whether you go in guns blazing, sneak in and line up your shots with a scope, or go tactical with VATS, it's fun.  Part of it is the endless crafting and customization, which extend to almost everything in the game.  The game is also quite funny.  Even as I sometimes cursed the limited dialogue options, I often enjoyed the black humor and amusing things my character said.

Do you like loot?  Fallout 4 has mountains of loot.  Hauling all that stuff back to a settlement you established and outfitting your settlers in godlike gear is great fun.  Finally, you have something to do with all your spare loot.  Yeah, the whole "defend your settlement from raiders" mechanic can get tedious when it interrupts your gameplay, but there are few things more awesome than seeing your settlers blow away mutated monsters with a minigun.

The game is often a bit on the easy side, but the highest difficulty turns the game into a fun survival-like experience where you have to find food, water, and shelter.  This introduces new gameplay elements and keeps things fresh.  It's a bit scary at first to play a Bethesda game with quick saves disabled, but Fallout 4 is pretty stable.

Fallout 4 is a great choice if you're looking for something a bit casual and streamlined that still has recognizable role-playing elements.  Fallout 4 is a different experience than the isometric Fallout games, which can be frustrating at times, but if you get over that, it's quite enjoyable.

148478314.review:
[h1]A Flawed Gem Revived by Mods[/h1]

Fallout 4, released in 2015 with high expectations, had its fair share of issues, from subpar graphics to a lackluster dialogue system. This exploration will delve into the numerous shortcomings of the base game while highlighting the incredible transformation it undergoes when paired with mods. Fallout 4, despite its issues, has been revived and rejuvenated by a passionate modding community that has turned this flawed gem into a shining masterpiece.

Before we delve into the incredible world of mods that have revitalized Fallout 4, it's important to discuss the significant flaws that plagued the vanilla game upon release. These flaws encompass various aspects, from graphics and performance to storytelling and role-playing elements.

One of the most glaring issues in Fallout 4 was its outdated graphics engine. Despite the game's release in 2015, it was running on the Creation Engine, a modified version of the engine used for The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim. This choice resulted in graphics that felt dated, with texture quality, character models, and facial animations falling behind contemporary standards.

Furthermore, Fallout 4 suffered from performance problems on both consoles and PC. Frame rate drops, stuttering, and game crashes were not uncommon, especially in areas with more complex geometry or crowded with NPCs. These performance issues hindered the immersion and overall enjoyment of the game.

The dialogue system in Fallout 4 also received heavy criticism. Unlike its predecessors, which offered nuanced and morally complex dialogue choices, Fallout 4 introduced a simplified system with four response options, often boiling down to "Yes," "No," "Sarcastic," or "Tell me more." This stripped-down approach eliminated much of the role-playing depth and left players feeling like they had less control over their character's personality and choices.

Fallout 4's role-playing elements were notably shallow compared to previous titles in the series. The skill and attribute system was replaced with a simplified perk system, and the removal of the Karma system meant that player choices had fewer far-reaching consequences. The lack of a true karma system and a scarcity of significant moral choices left many players feeling that their decisions had less impact on the game world.

While the main quest of Fallout 4 had its moments, many players found the story less engaging and thought-provoking compared to the intricate narratives of Fallout 3 and New Vegas. The lack of branching story paths and the linear structure of the main questline further diminished the game's replayability.

Despite its flaws, Fallout 4 became a prime example of the power of the modding community in rejuvenating a game. Modders from around the world took it upon themselves to address many of the game's shortcomings and enhance its overall experience. Let's explore some of the ways in which mods have transformed Fallout 4.

One of the first areas modders targeted was graphics. Several mod projects, such as "Fallout 4 HD Reworked Project," "NAC X," and "Vivid Fallout," have drastically improved the game's visuals. These mods enhance texture quality, lighting, and weather effects, bringing the Commonwealth wasteland to life with a level of detail and immersion that the base game could not achieve.

Modders have also focused on character models and animations, creating mods like "LooksMenu" and "Caliente's Beautiful Bodies Enhancer" to overhaul character creation and customization. With these mods, players can create more detailed and realistic characters, adding depth to their role-playing experience.

To address the game's performance issues, modders developed several stability and optimization mods. These mods help alleviate frame rate drops and reduce stuttering, providing a smoother gaming experience. By addressing memory and resource management, modders have significantly improved Fallout 4's overall performance.

For those disappointed by the simplified dialogue system, mods such as "Full Dialogue Interface" reintroduce a more traditional dialogue wheel, providing players with a clearer understanding of their character's responses. Additionally, mods like "Start Me Up - Alternate Start and Dialogue Overhaul" enable a more diverse role-playing experience by allowing players to choose alternative origins and narratives, breaking free from the pre-established backstory of the Sole Survivor.

While Fallout 4's main story may have left some players wanting more, modders have stepped in to fill the void with high-quality quest mods. Projects like "Frost," "Tales from the Commonwealth," and "Project Valkyrie" offer new storylines, unique characters, and intricate questlines that rival the quality of official Bethesda content. These mods expand the world of Fallout 4, introducing fresh adventures and exploration opportunities.

Mods have also made significant improvements to gameplay and mechanics. "Sim Settlements" revolutionizes settlement building by allowing settlers to construct their own homes and structures, bringing more life to the Commonwealth. Additionally, "Arbitration" and "War of the Commonwealth" ramp up the difficulty and intensity of combat, making the wasteland a more dangerous and thrilling place.

The modding community for Fallout 4 is remarkably active and collaborative, with modders often working together to create comprehensive experiences. Modding platforms like Nexus Mods provide a central hub for modders to share their creations and receive feedback. This sense of community support has enabled modders to push the boundaries of what Fallout 4 can offer.

In conclusion, Fallout 4, while a deeply flawed game upon release, has experienced a renaissance thanks to the dedication of the modding community. The tireless work of modders has transformed the game from a dated and frustrating experience into a dynamic, immersive, and highly replayable masterpiece. The power of Fallout 4's modding community serves as a testament to the resilience of the gaming community and the transformative potential of mods in modern gaming. The flaws of Fallout 4 became opportunities for passionate modders to reinvigorate a game that, in many ways, surpasses its predecessors. With the help of mods, Fallout 4 stands as a shining example of how player-driven creativity and dedication can turn a flawed gem into a masterpiece that continues to capture the imaginations of players worldwide.

148472944.review:
Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Fallout 4, the latest installment in Bethesda's beloved post-apocalyptic RPG series, has kept me immersed in its wasteland for a substantial 98 hours. My journey in the Commonwealth, with and without mods, has been a mix of captivating storytelling, exploration, and modifiable gameplay, but not without its quirks.

One of the standout features of Fallout 4 is its compelling and emotionally charged narrative. As the Sole Survivor searching for your lost son in the aftermath of a nuclear apocalypse, the game is filled with emotional weight. Your journey through the wasteland, interacting with various factions and colorful characters, makes for an engaging storytelling experience.

The Commonwealth, Fallout 4's rendition of post-apocalyptic Massachusetts, offers a grim and atmospheric open world. Ruined cityscapes, irradiated swamps, and underground hideouts create a setting rich in detail and history. The addition of dynamic weather and a day-night cycle adds to the immersion.

The crafting and settlement-building system is a substantial addition, allowing players to modify and build structures, weapons, and armor. This feature can be immensely satisfying, as you tailor your surroundings and gear to your playstyle, and it significantly extends gameplay hours. However, it can be a bit daunting for those looking for a more straightforward experience.

Combat in Fallout 4 has improved over its predecessors. The V.A.T.S. system, which lets you target specific body parts and slow down time during combat, is engaging and strategic. Gunplay feels more polished, and the addition of melee combat options provides variety. However, combat can sometimes be hampered by the game's occasionally glitchy mechanics, especially with mods.

I've played Fallout 4 both with and without mods, and the modding community for the game is extensive. Mods can enhance graphics, introduce new quests, and alter gameplay mechanics, offering a high level of customization. The modding community's dedication to the game is commendable, as it keeps the experience fresh and adds replay value.

On the downside, Fallout 4 has its share of technical hiccups. Bugs and performance issues, especially when heavily modded, can occasionally hinder the experience. While Bethesda has made efforts to address some of these issues with patches, they can still be frustrating.

In conclusion, Fallout 4 is a solid entry in the Fallout series, offering a rich narrative, an expansive open world, and extensive modding potential. Playing for 98 hours, I've appreciated the game's storytelling and crafting systems, though the technical issues and occasionally unpolished mechanics do detract from the overall experience. Whether you're a seasoned wasteland survivor or a newcomer to the series, Fallout 4 offers a compelling post-apocalyptic adventure with the added bonus of endless modding possibilities.
